svg.text: Methodological Innovation for Environmental Health Research
XAI-DLNM Framework: Bridging Data-Driven Discovery and Epidemiological Validation
ENBEL Conference: Advancing Environmental Health Methods for African Urban Populations
Addressing data scarcity and population-specific health vulnerabilities in Low- and Middle-Income Countries

g.text: • May not apply to African populations
Data-driven insights for environmental health policy
Novel approach bridging ML and epidemiology
EXPECTED IMPACT ON ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH RESEARCH
First framework combining XAI discovery with epidemiological validation for African populations
Evidence-based interventions for climate-health adaptation in resource-constrained urban settings
Novel insights into African urban health vulnerabilities
Transferable methodology for LMICs environmental health research
This methodological framework represents ongoing research. Final validation and results pending completion of DLNM analysis.
• Lundberg, S. M., & Lee, S. I. (2017). A unified approach to interpreting model predictions. NIPS, 4765-4774.
• Gasparrini, A., et al. (2010). Distributed lag non-linear models. Statistics in Medicine, 29(21), 2224-2234.
• Chen, T., & Guestrin, C. (2016). XGBoost: A scalable tree boosting system. ACM SIGKDD, 785-794.
• Watts, N., et al. (2021). The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change. Lancet, 397(10269), 129-170.

svg.text: ENBEL Conference 2025 | Methodological Innovation for Environmental Health | African Urban Research
